Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Fluid-driven Fracture of Elastic Materials, Flowback Dynamics and the Effect of Proppants

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1509347 (Stone)

The goal of the proposed research is to explore fluid dynamics phenomena that are related to hydraulic fracturing - an area of national importance for domestic energy production. The work proposed is based on fundamental theoretical analysis and elegant experiments conducted in simplified and very well-controlled systems of gelatin to model an elastic geological formation.

When the pressure is relieved after hydraulic cracking of an elastic material, the fluid can flow back. This is a process that occurs in hydraulic fracturing and has implications for the production of hydrocarbons as well as for the environment, since hydraulic fracking fluids need to be monitored in the subsurface. In contrast to fluid-driven cracking of elastic materials, for which there is a substantial theoretical literature but only limited experiments, there is a much smaller literature on flowback when the pressure controlling injection is released. This proposal is about laboratory experiments and mathematical modeling to (i) understand and characterize the coupled fluid flow and elastic stresses of fluid-driven cracking followed by flowback as the elastic stresses relax, and (ii) will do so including a particle-laden fluid (the proppant). The experiments will make use of gelatin materials that are elastic but brittle and have been described previously in the solid-earth geophysics literature for the study of fluid-driven cracks. Hence, there will be a link between fluid injection and flowback to the elastic response of the bulk material, with results interpreted using appropriately scaled quantities and dimensional analysis. These experimental and modeling efforts will be among the first to describe the dynamics of flowback and the role of the proppant. Graduate students will be involved in research and a series of outreach lectures, the Harvard and Princeton holiday lectures on engineering and science for children and families, will be offered based on the research findings of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are many problems in the world around us that involve either fluid flows or the deformation of (elastic) materials. Some problems involve both, as, for example, when a fluid is injected into an elastic material, a fracture forms and the fluid penetrates as the crack grows. In fact, in the case of hydraulic fracturing for production of oil and gas from shale reservoirs, which has risen rapidly over the past decades as a major energy source for the United States, there is little fundamental understanding of important processes that impact the energy production and the environment impact. We developed an laboratory-scale experimental system to study similar “fluid-elastic” problems, and coupled our measurements with mathematical modeling so as to understand these problems quantitatively and more mechanistically. In particular, we studied both the fluid-driven fracture (figure 1) as well as the “flow back” (figure 2) when the driving pressure was released and the relaxation of the elastic material forces the fluid back out of the crack, which represents the final step in liquid collection in industrial hydrofracture.  As a final aspect of the work we studied foam-driven fracture, as such industrial processes, using pressurized foams to create a fracture network, are known to offer a more sustainable approach (they utilize less water) to hydrofracture operations. We believe these kinds of laboratory and coupled mathematical models are one step toward helping to inform the public about the movements of fluids and particles in underground processes relevant to energy systems. As part of my engagement with broader impacts, I continue to train and mentor undergraduate students, graduate students and postdocs, publish papers with my research group in leading journals, serve the community by handling administrative tasks for research journals, give research-oriented lectures to summer research students, and yearly give a special holiday science lecture to children and families (four presentations in Boston and Princeton) on a new theme each year.
